title: GOP govs aim to avoid Romney missteps
content:
The midterms bring 36 governor ’ s races , with 22 incumbents on the ballot . GOP govs aim to avoid Romney falls
SCOTTSDALE , Ariz. — Republican governors ramping up reelection campaigns in states carried by Barack Obama want voters to know two things : they are not Mitt Romney , and they are not the obstructionist congressional GOP .
One year removed from the presidential campaign and one year before they face voters , the GOP chief executives are the bright spots of a party whose national brand is in tatters .
The midterms bring 36 governor ’ s races , with 22 incumbents on the ballot . Nine of those are Republicans in states Obama carried twice , including mega-states like Ohio , Florida , Michigan and Pennsylvania .
In a non-presidential year , the electorate will be friendlier – older , whiter and more conservative – but these incumbents know they need to win at least some voters who backed Obama .
From the vantage point of these governors , Romney lost not because he was too conservative but because he let Democrats define him , came off as heartless and did nothing to avoid being linked with unpopular congressional Republicans . Plus , the Obama field operation was vastly superior .
They grumble about the D.C. antics that led to the shutdown , which they widely believe was a main cause for Ken Cuccinelli ’ s defeat in Virginia ’ s off-year election .
Here are the four main lessons that chief executives in battleground states take from the party ’ s recent troubles , according to nearly two dozen interviews with governors and party strategists at the Republican Governors Association meeting this week .
Fair or not , the prevailing consensus is that Romney never outlined a hopeful and optimistic vision for the future , instead trying to make the election a referendum on Obama . Fleshing out details , the Republican worried , would only put a target on his back .
“ That ’ s a mistake , ” said Louisiana Gov . Bobby Jindal , the vice chairman of the RGA . “ If you don ’ t define yourself , one , you don ’ t deserve the job because you need a mandate from the people to make the changes you want to make . But , secondly , you ’ re giving your opponent the chance to tell the voters who you are . ”
Republican incumbents are in a different boat than Romney was because they have a four-year record to run on , which in many cases includes passing far-reaching legislation . But the Romney experience has persuaded many that they can not just go negative on their opponent – they must sell what they ’ ve done and develop a few big ideas for a second term .
“ I thought there could have been more presentation of ‘ why Romney ’ as opposed to ‘ why not the president , ’ ” said Michigan Gov . Rick Snyder , who carries a list of accomplishments in his suit pocket and is quick to outline what his priorities would be in a second term .
Until October 2012 , Romney rarely discussed his record as governor in Massachusetts . He was afraid to mention his signature achievement during his single term – Romneycare – for fear it would turn off the base and blunt his criticisms of Obamacare .
Indiana Gov . Mike Pence , elected last year , wants Republicans to lay out how they would improve health care in their states if the Affordable Care Act was successfully repealed .
“ You can not beat a program without a program , ” he said .
“ It ’ s not enough just to say , ‘ drill , baby , drill , ’ ” he said . “ We need to talk about what energy independence really means . ”
2 ) Break with the national Republican brand by running against Washington .
Governors in blue and purple states are somewhat cautious about bashing Obama too aggressively because they need some crossover voters . But they have become increasingly willing to criticize Beltway Republicans .
At the RGA meeting , governors blamed many problems in their state on headwinds created by dysfunction and gridlock .
“ The only thing we see exported out of D.C. is insanity , ” said Florida Gov . Rick Scott . “ This country is doing better because of Republican governors . But , DC , it ’ s pure insanity what ’ s coming out of there . ”
Romney did not break with congressional Republicans because he was afraid of alienating his base . He picked Paul Ryan , who authored the controversial House Republican budget , as his running mate .
Contrast that to George W. Bush , who famously chastised congressional Republicans in 1999 for trying to “ balance their budget on the backs of the poor . ”
content_original:
The midterms bring 36 governor’s races, with 22 incumbents on the ballot. GOP govs aim to avoid Romney falls

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Republican governors ramping up reelection campaigns in states carried by Barack Obama want voters to know two things: they are not Mitt Romney, and they are not the obstructionist congressional GOP.

One year removed from the presidential campaign and one year before they face voters, the GOP chief executives are the bright spots of a party whose national brand is in tatters.

Story Continued Below

The midterms bring 36 governor’s races, with 22 incumbents on the ballot. Nine of those are Republicans in states Obama carried twice, including mega-states like Ohio, Florida, Michigan and Pennsylvania.

( PHOTOS: Governors’ offices up for grabs in 2014)

In a non-presidential year, the electorate will be friendlier – older, whiter and more conservative – but these incumbents know they need to win at least some voters who backed Obama.

From the vantage point of these governors, Romney lost not because he was too conservative but because he let Democrats define him, came off as heartless and did nothing to avoid being linked with unpopular congressional Republicans. Plus, the Obama field operation was vastly superior.

They grumble about the D.C. antics that led to the shutdown, which they widely believe was a main cause for Ken Cuccinelli’s defeat in Virginia’s off-year election.

( QUIZ: How well do you know Ken Cuccinelli?)

Here are the four main lessons that chief executives in battleground states take from the party’s recent troubles, according to nearly two dozen interviews with governors and party strategists at the Republican Governors Association meeting this week.

1) Offer specifics, and run on your record.

Fair or not, the prevailing consensus is that Romney never outlined a hopeful and optimistic vision for the future, instead trying to make the election a referendum on Obama. Fleshing out details, the Republican worried, would only put a target on his back.

“That’s a mistake,” said Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, the vice chairman of the RGA. “If you don’t define yourself, one, you don’t deserve the job because you need a mandate from the people to make the changes you want to make. But, secondly, you’re giving your opponent the chance to tell the voters who you are.”

( PHOTOS: Election Day 2013)

Republican incumbents are in a different boat than Romney was because they have a four-year record to run on, which in many cases includes passing far-reaching legislation. But the Romney experience has persuaded many that they cannot just go negative on their opponent – they must sell what they’ve done and develop a few big ideas for a second term.

“I thought there could have been more presentation of ‘why Romney’ as opposed to ‘why not the president,’” said Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder, who carries a list of accomplishments in his suit pocket and is quick to outline what his priorities would be in a second term.

Until October 2012, Romney rarely discussed his record as governor in Massachusetts. He was afraid to mention his signature achievement during his single term – Romneycare – for fear it would turn off the base and blunt his criticisms of Obamacare.

Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, elected last year, wants Republicans to lay out how they would improve health care in their states if the Affordable Care Act was successfully repealed.

“You cannot beat a program without a program,” he said.

Jindal is helping candidates to flesh out specifics.

“It’s not enough just to say, ‘drill, baby, drill,’” he said. “We need to talk about what energy independence really means.”

2) Break with the national Republican brand by running against Washington.

Governors in blue and purple states are somewhat cautious about bashing Obama too aggressively because they need some crossover voters. But they have become increasingly willing to criticize Beltway Republicans.

At the RGA meeting, governors blamed many problems in their state on headwinds created by dysfunction and gridlock.

“The only thing we see exported out of D.C. is insanity,” said Florida Gov. Rick Scott. “This country is doing better because of Republican governors. But, DC, it’s pure insanity what’s coming out of there.”

Romney did not break with congressional Republicans because he was afraid of alienating his base. He picked Paul Ryan, who authored the controversial House Republican budget, as his running mate.

Contrast that to George W. Bush, who famously chastised congressional Republicans in 1999 for trying to “balance their budget on the backs of the poor.”
